Good question how do I deal with old fashion questions. Answer: First it depends on the subject matter of the old questions and whether it’s a general or specific question. With that in mind: I deal with old fashion questions the same way I deal with all questions, with honesty, unless it involves my serious personal privacy then it depends who’s asking the question and why they want the private information. For example, hypothetically, if the BOBs were asking me questions concerning my privacy I would simple tell them “Sorry, I wish I could help you with your inquiry. Unfortunately, you are not a “resource” that can be trusted.” Hypothetically speaking, if your Grandmother asked me something personal I would simply answer her question in a simple, direct and honest manner. If it was a old-fashion question that would justify an updated more modern or current answer I would submit an answer that addresses the question in an old fashion content first then tell the listener “However, currently this is how it would be answered and then demonstrate the answer it in a more current manner.” This way the person asking the old fashion question can select the most appropriate answer to the old fashion question being asked. Peace, Randy

Hi. When you say “old fashioned ‘opinions,’” I think “Timeless Wisdom.” Skirt lengths and ties, or don't go out alone? Specificity is necessary for this type of question. Certain safety protocols are timeless. Whether you wear holes in your jeans is a matter of personal preference and should be encouraged as an individual deems appropriate to their own style. Same goes for piercings and tatts. Your body is Your sanctuary. I encourage health, but unless you are a minor or professional where company policy draws lines, you should be yourself in your appearance (as long as you wear Something.) I refuse to touch on politics. Keep in mind, respect is Always deserved by our elders. They have seen and been through things we cannot imagine.

It is hard, because these people probably don’t have an open mindset so it’s hard to convince them that you know what you’re doing. If possible, try to avoid talking to these people (for instance, if it’s your neighbour or someone you met at the grocery store). If it’s someone close to you or a member of your family, you can either ignore their opinions and wait until they stop talking about it, or you can calmly sit down with them and try to explain, that you have a different opinion and that they should respect it. Good luck!

Depends on the opinion. Many old fashioned opinions are ground in a perspective of that era, and some transcend to our time as well. In my opinion, if the old fashioned opinion is ground in respect, patience, and honor, then it most likely will apply to most situations and is something to consider being relevant to today’s standards. Many old fashioned opinions were born out of those traits, unlike today many standards are based on selfishness and desires.

Old fashioned is really a loaded term. It could refer to family values, integrity, responsibility, etc. Or it could mean opinions from older people whom you disagree with. I’m guessing that’s it. I’m going to suggest you deal with it the same way I deal with the opinions of millennials: I listen and see if there is merit it what they say. If there is, I consider it and maybe even alter my own opinion.

Funny thing about opinions is everyone has one, you’re not going to agree with a lot of them, but you should always be respectful of others no matter how absurd and Obscure they may seem. Always do your own research, this will help weed out the bullshit from the truth.
I accept that outdated opinion as theirs and then move on with my life. I don’t live my life to impress anyone and never asked for their opinion.
